THE TERRITORY. Territory of Nebraska was organized May loth, lv"4 The Territory was a part of the Louisiana Purchase ceded by France to the United States in 1X03. First Territorial Legislature held at Omaha commencing January 15th, 1*55, consisting of 13 Councilman and 25 Representatives and the 12th and last session convened al Omaha January 19th, 1867. The seat of Government was permanently located at Lancaster, the present site of Lincoln. July 29th, 1.HG7. The Territory sent 3,157 men to the Union armits during the Civil \\ THE STATE Eebraska was admitted to the Union as a State March :?■ t of Congress passed February 9th, 1867, and by Proclamation is by President Andrew Johnson and attested by Hon. William H ■d. Secretary of State, and dated March 1st of that year. The first State Legislature was held in Lincoln January 7th The present Constitution was adopted November 1st, 1875. The extreme length of the State east and west is 412 n IU greatest breadth north and south is 208 miles. Its area is 76,895 square miles or 4!t,iML > ,iM>0 acre Number of votes cast in 1868—9,77.' Piper Chief Clerk TRANSACTIONS OF BOARDS The report of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds will be found in the report of the Commissioner of Public Lands and Buildings, which will also contain the transactions of the Board of Purchase and Kie action of the Board of Equalization and Assessment will be in the report of the Auditor of Public Accounts, which will also i the transactions of the Board to Approve Depository Bonds. The Board of Canvassers has canvassed the vote on the Constitu tional Amendment, the latter having failed of the required majority vote The Board of Prison Inspectors will be included in the report of the Warden of the State Penitentiary. The Secretary of State is secretary of the Printing Board, and a» itemized statement of its business will be found in the report, which is published herewith, by its secretary, Harry Thomas. LEGISLATIVE RECOMMENDATIONS Corporations corporation law of 1H C .»7, which provides for the filing of arti - of all corporations with the Secretary of State, based the filing fee the authorized capital stock. This law remained unchanged until legislature of 1*07, when an amendment was passed increasing the filing fee from ten cents to fifty cents per thousand. When this bill was drawn the word "authorized" was omitted, which was a clerical error, as the party who drew the measure informed me that it was not intentionally left out, and as the laws of other states, which we have examined, specify that the fee should be based on the "authorized" capital stock, I would recommend to the Legislature that the present law be changed so that the fee will be based on the "authorized" capi - tal stock instead of "capital stock." The law created two years ago imposing an annual tax upon all corporations, both domestic and foreign, has demonstrated the fact that the same is not perfect, and a few amendments should be made to that law. I would recommend that the fee be a per centum based upon the "paid up" and "subscribed" capital foreign corporations doing busines: quired to pay upon such proportion erty located or used in this State property and capital outside of the i stock of the corporation, and that in this State should only be re- of their capital stock as their prop - bears to the total amount of their ;tate. Permanent School Investment Fund. I want to join with the other members of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds, which Board has the investing of the permanent school fund in Nebraska in a request that the Legislature make pro - vision for the disposing of State bonds of other states held by this State for this investment fund, when such bonds can be sold at par without any loss whatever to the State, and the money so derived for said bonds can then be re-invested in municipal and school bonds in this State. At present there are between three and four million dollars invested in state securities outside of Nebraska, which are drawing in - terest from three and a quarter to four per cent. These bonds could be disposed of and the money brought home and invested in Nebraska securities at four and four and one-half per cent, which would be a saving in the rate that is being paid at present by the issuers of the bonds, and also increase the income of the school fund from one-half to one per cent, and I believe that the funds invested in these securities

16 Eld be safer than having it Invested in long time bonds of some of states that are in a class which will require years before they are to pay any on the principal. Pie Board has within the last jremr and a half refused something million dollars in bonds which luive been offered by school dis - and municipalities in this State, and this should not be tfc Nebraska has money Invested in securities of other States. I respectfulh I that the correction herein reconunendet icorporated into law. Metal Fixtures in Vault. I would recommend, and do most earnestly hope the Legislature will make an appropriation for supplying metal fixtures for at least one of the two vaults in this Department. These vaults at present are sup - plied with nothing but combustible material, and in case of fire it is ■ loubtful but that all the records would be destroyed. These vaults are filled with Legislative Records dating from the first session to the present time, all the original manuscript of laws, contracts for all work or material, bonds of state officers, notarial records, election records and a great many other documents that could not be replaced. Automobiles E years ago when I assumed control of this Department there istered ten hundred and eighty-seven automobiles. At the pres - there are over fifteen thousand on record. The original law for the issuing of a license, but in I!iu7 the Legislature amended it so that the licenses are now issued annually. It is the cus - tom of this department, the first of every month, to notify all automo - bile owners whose license expires during that month of the fact, and as this requires the sending out of fifteen thousand notifications, and an equal amount in remitting the license, together with the issuing of licenses for new machines, (which amounts to upward of five thousand per year) the work has become so great in its proportions that it re - quires almost the entire time of one person. Therefore we have asked in our appropriation for office expenses sufficient to cover the salary of one clerk for at least twelve months during the biennium, which will be absolutely necessary if we are to give the prompt service that is expected of a state department. Increased Office Expenses. The biennium preceding the time that we assumed charge this De - partment collected in fees $22,463.10, with an office appropriation of $20,180.00. During this biennium we have turned into the state treas - ury fees collected to the amount of 1322,686.81 on an office appropria - tion of $25,280. It will be apparent, with this increased labor thrown on the office of Secretary of State in collecting this large amount of funds, that the office appropriations are not in keeping with the increase in fees. During the last two years this office has been compelled to

RKPORT OF TH1 1ARY OF STATK 17 withhold a great deal of information, which, though legally we are not compelled to give, yet would have been of great advantage to those having business to perform with this Department, solely on account of not having sufficient money to pay for stationery and stamps and extra clerical hire in getting the work out, and we believe that it is a bad practice for the State not to give all information and aid possible to our citizens. Such, however, cannot be done unless the Legislature makes sufficient appropriation to do so. Therefore we have asked for an appropriation for office expenses that will allow this Department to give good service to the public, and we trust that the Legislature will recognize the large increase in the 'Cted thru this Department, which has necessarily demanded a much larger amount of labor, and be willing to return at least a small portion of it to help put the laws into operation, and render proper and efficient service to the public. Respectfully submitted Secretary of State. OFFICE EXPENSES. 18 REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE REPORT OF STATE PRINTING BOARD During the biennium ending November 30th, 1910, the State Print - ing Board has secured bids upon and awarded contracts for approxi - mately ft;_ vorth of printing and sationery supplies for the ous departments and institutions of the state. Of this sum approxi - mately $23 luta been expended for the publication of the annual and semi-annual reports of the State Officers, Supreme Court Reports and the Journals of the Senate and House of Representatives of the Session of 1!< The volume of business handled by the State Printing Board makes it impracticable to give a detailed statement of each transaction. How - ever, the numerous small items have been purchased at prices which have been fair to the state, and at the same time giving a reasonable profit to the successful bidder. During the biennium five meetings of the Printing Board have been held for awarding contracts for work for the various state offices and institutions. For each letting a tabulated schedule is prepared giv - ing full information regarding the work on which bids are askeO. the names of the bidders, amounts of the bids and the name of the success - ful bidder; the schedules being bound as a part of the records of the board. At each of the five lettings competition has been keen and as a result the work has been distributed among various printing estab - lishments of the state. The number of bidders at each letting has averaged from three to nineteen. For several years the State Printing Board has been equipped with a set of paper testing devices, including testers for strength, thickness and weight, the value of these instruments to the state has been set forth in full in previous reports from this department. A great number of contracts for emergency printing have been during the past biennium, which have, in every case, been let by e bidding to the lowest bidder Salary of Bookkeeper, fifteen hundred dollars Three thousand dollars for the biennium o ...$1,: ...$3,000.00 Salary of Corporation Clerk, fifteen hundred dollars.. "closely build (t) ui portions,' sh n the territory of a city, town or v ill ntiguous a. public highway devoted to business or where for not than one-fourth :i mile the dwelling houses on such highway avera not more tt mndred et apart Fee One Dollar Per Year. Sec. 2. Every owner of a motor vehicle shall, for every such vehicle owned by him, file in the office of the Secretary c: statement of his name and address, with a brief description cf the vehicle to be registered, on a blank prepared and furnished by such Secretary for that purpose. The fee shall be fl.io per year, and must accompany the application for registration and license; subsequent pay - ments must be made on, or before the date of expiration of said regis - tration and license, which is for one year from date thereof. For regis - tering change of ownership the fee shall be $l.i- rtified copy of the bill of sale must accompany such application. Sec. 3. The secretary of state shall thereupon file such a state - ment in his office, register such motor vehicle in a book to be kept for that purpose and assign it a number beginning with number one (1) and so on in the order of filing. File Application. Sec. 4. Every person acquiring a motor vehicle shall file a like statement with the secretary of the state and such secretary of the state shall, in like manner, file such statement. h vehicle and assign it a number. Assignments. If the vehicle has previously been registered, and such fact and For an Act requiring and regul ] Nebraaki purix ude all vehicles propelled by any

24 REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE number assigned it shall be set forth in the statement, and the previous registration shall be cancelled; but the number of such previous regis - tration may be assigned under the new registration. Sec. 5. The secretary of state shall forthwith on such registration and without other fee, issue and deliver to the owner of such motor, vehicle, a seal of aluminum or other suitable metal which shall be circular in form, not over two (2) inches in diameter, and have stamped thereon the words "Registered in the office of the Secretary of State for the State of Nebraska" under the motor law Xo with the registration number inserted therein; which seal shall thereafter at all times be conspicuously displayed on the motor vehicle to which such number has been assigned. Must Display Number and Neb. ESec. 6. Every motor vehicle shall also at all times have the num - assigned to it by the Secretary of State displayed on the back of motor vehicle in such a manner as to be plainly visible, the num - ber to be Arabian numerals, each not less than three (3) inches in height and each stroke to be of a width not less than one-half (> 2 ) inch and also as a part of such number the abbreviated letters of the State Ei viz: Neb., such letters to be not less than two (2) inches in t- Non-Residents. > r5ec. 7. The provisions of section two (2) to five inclusive shall apply to motor vehicles owned and operated by non-residents of this state, provided the owners thereof have complied with any law re - quiring the registration of owners of motor vehicles in force in the state, territor} or federal district of their residence, and the registra - tion number showing the initials of such state, territory or federal dis - trict shall bedisplayed on such vehicles substantially as providt;<l by sec - tion six (6) of this act. Rate of Speed Sec. 8. No person shall operate a motor vehicle on a public high - way at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper ha\ing regard to the traffic and use of the highway, or so as to endanger the life or limb of any person, or in tbe event in the close built up por - tions of a city, town or village, at a greater riite than one (1) mile in six minutes, or elsewhere in a city, town or village, at a greater rate than (1) mile in four (4) minutes, or elsewhere outside of the city, town or village, at a greater rate than twenty miles per hour, subject, however, to the other provisions of this section. Upon aproaching a crossing of intersecting public highways, or a bridge, or a sharp curve, or a steep descent, and also in traveling such crossings, bridges, curves, or descent, a person operating a motor vehicle shall have it under con - trol and operated at a rate of speed less than heretofore specified, and in no event greater than is reasonable and proper, having regard to the traffic then on such highways and the safety of the public.

REPORT OF THK I ARY OF STATE 25 c Sec. 9. Any person operating a motor vehicle shall at request or n signal by putting up the hand, from a person riding or driving a restive horse or other draught or domestic animal, bring such motor vehicle immediately to a stop, and, if traveling in the opposite direc - tion remain stationary so long as may be reasonable to allow such horse or animal to pass, and if traveling in the same direction, use reasonable caution in passing such horse or animals, and the operator of any motor vehicle shall render necessary assistance to the party having in charge such a horse or other draught animal in so passing. Signals. Sec. 10. Every motor vehicle while in use on a public highway shall be provided with good and sufficient brakes, and also with a suit - able bell, horn or other signal, and be so constructed as to exhibit dur- ng the period from o _• (1) hour after sunset to one (1) hour before sunrise, one or more lamps showing white lights visible wiihin a reason- able distance toward which such a vehicle is proceeding, and also red light visible in the reverse direction. Cities and Towns. Sec. 11. Cities and towns have no power to pass, enforce or main - tain any ordinance, rule or regulation requiring o fany owner or oper - ator of a motor vehicle any license or permit to use the public high - way or exclude or prohibit any motor vehicle whose owner has com - plied with section two (2) or section four (4) of this act from the free use of such highways, and all such ordinances, rules or regulations now in force, are hereby declared to be of no validity or effect; provided that nothing in this act shall be construed as limiting the power of local authorities to make and force and maintain an ordinance, rules or regulations, in addition to the provisions of this act, affecting motor vehicles which are offered to the public for hire. Publish List of Registrations. Sec. 12. The secretary of state may, at his discretion publish in pamphlet form the names of owners of motor vehicles who have reg - istered and pay the expense from the office expense fund of his depart - ment, providing such publication may be sold for not les than $1.00 per copy. The proceeds of said sale to be paid to the state treasurer foi - the general fund and miscellaneous fees. Penalty for Violation Sec. 13. The violation of a-.iy of the provisions of this act, shall b« deemed a misdemeanor, punishable by fine not exceeding twenty-flTe ($25.00) for the first offense, and punishable by a fine of not less than ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($5000) or imprisonment not ex - ceeding thirty days (30) in the county jail for a second or subsequent offense. Passed and approved April 3rd, II
